Executive Summary

Superior Pipeline Co. (SPC) owns and operates the natural gas treating and dehydration plant in Red Oak, Oklahoma. The plant is primarily designed to remove CO2 from incoming natural gas via amine treatment.  The plant also removes trace amounts of H2S and water vapor from natural gas via physical separation and dehydration.  Section 112(r ) of the Clean Air Act applies to the Panola plant because it handles a process flammable (methane).  The natural gas entering the plant is approximately 96% methane.  Methane exists in excess of threshold quantities within the process vessels and piping of the facility.  SPC management is aware of potential hazards posed by handling process flammables.  Programs have been established to prevent accidental releases and train personnel for emergency response in the event of a release. 

The accidental release and emergency response policies are detailed in the facility Emergency Response plan.  SPC has considered the impact of a "worst case" accident.  In this case, the ¿worst case¿ would be a total release of all methane being processed at the facility, resulting in the instantaneous formation of a vapor cloud which ignites and explodes. Using the EPA¿s RMP*Comp software version 1.07, the potential radius of impact, due to the explosion, was calculated to extend 0.2 miles.  Global positioning system (GPS) was utilized to estimate public receptors within a 1 mile radius.  It was determined that the worst case event would affect nearby structures, and there would be offsite consequences of such an explosion.  This event is highly un-likely, however a consideration of the 0.2 mile radius has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning.  SPC has reported zero accidents at the Panola plant in the past five years.  

SPC is implementing safety programs and procedures designed to prevent and mitigate catastrophic releases. Operation, maintenance, training, and inspection procedures are being

implemented.  In addition, SPC has coordinated with local emergency responders, including the Wilburton Fire Department, Panola Volunteer Fire Department, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee. Panola Plant personnel and responders will be required to participate in facility-specific training.

With these objectives in mind, this Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide information about our management of risks associated with natural gas treatment facility.  We stress our commitment to ensuring a safe operation for our employees, our visitors, and our community.


2.0 HAZARD ASSESSMENT PROCEDURES

The required elements of hazard assessment are as follows:
§68.25 Worst-case release scenario analysis
§68.28 Alternative release scenario analysis
§68.30 Defining offsite impacts - population
§68.33 Defining offsite impacts - environment
§68.36 Review and update
§68.39 Documentation
§68.42 Five-year accident history

2.1 Input Parameters (Applicability) ¿ §68.20 - §68.22

For the Panola gas treatment system, the process piping is where the worst-case release quantity is expected to reside.   According to the June 2007 analyses (Attachment 1), the estimated gas volume held in process equipment at the facility was 4,728.98 cubic feet.  The estimated volume for the process piping was based on approximately 10% of the equipment/vessel volumes, yielding 472.90 cubic feet and a total plant volume of 5,201.88 cubic feet.  Back pressure valves will not allow the plant operating pressure to exceed 850 psi.  Utilizing ideal gas law equations, the calculated density of methane at 850 psi and 150 degrees F is approximately 2.12 lb/cubic ft.   Therefore the amount of process methane is 11,027.99 lb which exceeds the 10,000 lb methane threshold for RMP applicability.  Methane is the only regulated substance at the facility.

Per §68.25(e), because the regulated flammable substance is a gas at ambient temperature and is handled as a gas or as a liquid under pressure, we

shall assume that the quantity in the vessel or pipe, as determined under 40 CFR §68.25(b)(2), is released as a gas over 10 minutes. 

2.2 Worst Case Scenario Analyses - §68.25

In this worst case scenario, the total quantity is assumed to be involved in a vapor cloud explosion (VCE).  An analyses of this explosion was done using RMP*Comp Version 1.07.

2.3 Defining Offsite Impacts - §68.30 

According to the model, offsite impacts will be limited to a 0.2 mile radius for a VCE and 0.1 mile radius for a VCF.  

Within the 0.2 mile radius of the facility, there are 3 bunkhouses utilized by onshore drilling personnel.  There is also a private residential home.  The total

population within the 0.2 mile radius is estimated to be less than 15 residents at any given time.   

There are no public receptors such as schools, hospitals, prisons, public recreational areas, arenas, major commercial or industrial developments within the affected area.  

There are no environmental receptors or natural areas such as national or state parks; forests or monuments; officially-designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or areas; or Federal wilderness areas within the affected area. 

2.4 Passive Mitigation

There are no structures that can contain and mitigate the worst-case release scenario.

2.6 Review and Update - §68.36

SPC will review and update the offsite consequence analyses at least once every five years.  If changes in processes, quantities stored or handled, or any other aspect of the stationary source might reasonably be expected to increase or decrease the worst-case distance to the endpoint by a factor of two or more, SPC will complete a revised analysis within six months of the change and submit a revised Risk Management Plan.

2.7 Five Year Accident History - §68.42

SPC has not recorded any accidents that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage, within the last five years.



3.0 PREVENTION PROGRAM 

3.1 Introduction

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Superior Gas Plant. Processes at the Superior Gas Plant that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP) regulation and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) process safety management (PSM) standard. This summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

3.2 Process Safety Information - §68.65:

The Superior Gas Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process. These documents address chemical processes and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, specific inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. The Operations Manager has assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. 
Chemical-specific information, including toxicity information, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reacti

rocess being analyzed.
Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP);
The HAZOP addresses:
(1) The hazards of the process;
(2) The identification of any previous incident which had a likely potential for catastrophic consequences.
(3) Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards and their interrelationships such as appropriate application of detection methodologies to provide early warning of releases. 
(4) Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls;
(5) Stationary source siting;
(6) Human factors; and
(7) A qualitative evaluation of a range of the possible safety and health effects of failure of controls.
The process hazard analysis was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations.  Don Love, Ph.D, P.E. facilitated the effort.  Dr. Love has over 50 years of experience and knowledge specific to the process being evaluated.  
SPC has established a system to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations.  SPC also assures that the recommendations are being resolved in a timely manner and that the resolutions are documented.  SPC has developed a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed.  SPC has communicated the actions to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.
The process hazard analysis will be updated and revalidated every 5 years, in accordance with CFR 1910.119(e), to assure consistency with the current process.  All MOC (Management of Change) items will be reviewed at the time of the re-evaluation to ensure all changes to the process are evaluated for hazards and hazard controls.  The updates or revalidations for each process, and the documented resolution of recommendations, will be kept for the life of the process.


3.4 Operating Procedures - §68.69
SPC continues to develop and revise operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activit

ices apply to SPC employees and contractor employees.
3.5 Training - §68.71
Each employee presently involved in operating a process, and each employee before being involved in operating a newly assigned process, is trained in an overview of the process and operating procedures as specified in §68.69.  The training includes emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.
Refresher training will be provided every three years, and more often if necessary, to each employee involved in operating a process to assure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process. SPC, in consultation with the employees involved in operating the process, shall determine the appropriate frequency of refresher training.
SPC will ascertain documentation that each employee involved in operating a process has received and understood the required training. SPC will prepare a record which contains the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.  Currently, on the job training occurs regularly and verification is ascertained through observation, demonstration, and oral testing.
3.6 Mechanical Integrity - §68.73   
The following process equipment is included in the SPC mechanical integrity program.
(1) Pressure vessels and storage tanks;
(2) Piping systems (including piping components such as valves);
(3) Relief and vent systems and devices;
(4) Emergency shutdown systems;
(5) Controls (including monitoring devices and sensors, alarms, and interlocks) and,
(6) Pumps.
SPC has established and implemented written procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of process equipment.  SPC trains each employee involved in maintaining the on-going integrity of process equipment.  The training provides an overview of each process, its hazards, and procedures applicable to the emplo

yee's job tasks.
Inspections and tests are performed on the regulated process equipment.   Inspection and testing procedures follow recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  The frequency of inspections and tests of process equipment is consistent with applicable manufacturers' recommendations and good engineering practices, and more frequently if determined to be necessary by prior operating experience.  In addition to the required inspection recommendations, SPC employees perform daily walkthroughs at the facility in order to identify potential hazards or concerns.  
SPC documents each inspection and test performed on process equipment. The documentation identifies the date of inspection or test, name of the person who performed the inspection or test, serial number, or other identifier of the equipment on which the inspection or test was performed.  In addition, a description of the inspection or test performed, and results of the inspection or test will be documented.
SPC corrects deficiencies in equipment that are outside acceptable limits (defined by the process safety information in §68.65) before further use or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to assure safe operation.
In the construction of new plants and equipment, SPC assures that fabricated equipment is suitable for the process application for which they will be used. Appropriate checks and inspections are performed to assure that equipment is installed properly and consistent with design specifications and the manufacturer's instructions. In addition, SPC will ensure that maintenance materials, spare parts and equipment are suitable for the process application for which they will be used.
Management of Change - §68.75   
SPC establishes and implements written procedures to manage changes (except for ¿replacements in kind¿) to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures; and, changes to stationary sources that affect a covered process.  The proc

ng followed.
The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  A report of the findings of the audit will be developed. The owner or operator will determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  SPC will retain the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports.
Incident Investigation - §68.81   
SPC health and safety personnel, along with operations personnel,  investigate each incident which resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Incident investigations are initiated as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours following the incident.
In the event of such an incident, an investigation team is established.  The team consists of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.
A report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and includes, at a minimum, the following:
(1) Date of incident;
(2) Date investigation began;
(3) A description of the incident;
(4) The factors that contributed to the incident; and,
(5) Any recommendations resulting from the investigation.
SPC has established a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions are documented.  In addition, the report is reviewed with all affected personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings.  The review also includes contract employees where applicable.  These incident investigation reports are retained for five years.
Employee Participation - §68.83   
Employee participation is a key element of this program.  SPC will develop a written plan of action regarding the implementation of the employee partici

pation.  SPC will consult with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of process hazards analyses and on the development of the other elements of process safety management in this rule.  SPC will provide to employees and their representatives; access to process hazard analyses, and to all other information required to be developed under this rule.
Hot Work Permit - §68.85 
SPC issues a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.  The permit documents fire prevention and protection requirements in 29 CFR 1910.252(a) prior to beginning the hot work operations; it indicates the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identifies the object on which hot work is to be performed. The permit is kept on file until completion of the hot work operations. 



Contractors §68.87 
This section applies to contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process. It does not apply to contractors providing incidental services which do not influence process safety, such as janitorial work, food and drink services, laundry, delivery or other supply services.
SPC develops and implements safe work practices consistent with §68.69(d).  SPC controls the entrance, presence, and exit of the contract owner or operator and contract employees in covered process areas.  Contractors are required to sign in and out when entering process areas.  Job Safety Analyses (JSAs) are generated to create awareness of hazards associated with specific tasks.  SPC personnel conduct regular informal ¿tailgate meetings¿ in order to cover hazards associated with individual tasks.  In addition, SPC has held and will continue to hold formal meetings with contractors to cover safety expectations and obligations of the contract holder.  These activities and requirements allow SPC to inform the contract owner or operator of the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards

related to the contractor's work and the process. In addition, SPC explains the applicable provisions of subpart E (emergency response) of this part.
SPC is developing methods that will improve its ability to evaluate contractor safety programs and performance.  SPC will ensure the contract owner or operator is fulfilling their obligations.  These obligations include: 
(1) assurance that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job; 
(2)the contract owner, operator, or supervision shall assure that each contract employee is instructed in the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to his/her job and the process, and the applicable provisions of the emergency action plan.
(3) The contract owner or operator shall document that each contract employee has received and understood the training required by this section. The contract owner or operator shall prepare a record which contains the identity of the contract employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.
(4) The contract owner or operator shall assure that each contract employee follows the safety rules of the stationary source including the safe work practices required by §68.69(d).
(5) The contract owner or operator shall advise the owner or operator of any unique hazards presented by the contract owner or operator's work, or of any hazards found by the contract owner or operator's work.
